quote:
All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost;
The old that is strong does not wither,
Deep roots are not reached by the frost.

From the ashes a fire shall be woken,
A light from the shadows shall spring;
Renewed shall be blade that was broken,
The crownless again shall be king.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All that is gold does not glitter,
Not all those who wander are lost;
The old that is strong does not wither,
Deep roots are not reached by the frost.

From the ashes a fire shall be woken,
A light from the shadows shall spring;
Renewed shall be blade that was broken,
The crownless again shall be king.
summary: This quote teaches us that true value and strength often aren't obvious. Something precious might not look flashy, and someone who seems to be aimlessly wandering might actually be on a meaningful path. It also emphasizes that things with deep, strong foundations will endure difficult times, just as deep roots are protected from the cold. Furthermore, it offers a hopeful message: even after destruction or despair, new life and light will emerge, what was broken will be restored, and those who lost their power or rightful place will eventually reclaim it.

quote: Not all those who wander are lost.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Not all those who wander are lost.
summary: This quote means that someone who appears to be wandering or not following a conventional path is not necessarily without purpose or direction. It challenges the common assumption that a lack of a clear, fixed destination automatically implies confusion or aimlessness. Instead, it suggests that exploring, deviating, or taking an unconventional route can be a deliberate choice, leading to discovery, learning, and finding one's own unique way, even if the journey looks different to others.

quote:
I wish it need not have happened in my time," said Frodo.
"So do I," said Gandalf, "and so do all who live to see such times. But that is not for them to decide. All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.

summary: Frodo expresses a common wish that difficult and unwelcome events weren't happening during his time. Gandalf agrees that everyone living through such challenging periods feels the same way. However, he emphasizes that people don't get to choose when these major events occur. Instead of dwelling on the timing, the only thing anyone can decide is how they choose to act and what they do with the time and circumstances they are given.

quote: I don't know half of you half as well as I should like; and I like less than half of you half as well as you deserve.

Second, for a smaller group of people, the speaker admits that while they may not like them very much, those individuals actually deserve more affection and appreciation than the speaker currently gives them.

quote: All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us.
summary: This quote suggests that the most important decision we face in life is how we choose to use the limited time we are given. It emphasizes that our lives are finite, and the true challenge or opportunity lies not in simply having time, but in how we spend each moment, make choices, and direct our actions. Essentially, it reminds us that our greatest power lies in deciding what we do with our days, our energy, and our opportunities.

quote: If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: If more of us valued food and cheer and song above hoarded gold, it would be a merrier world.
summary: This quote suggests that if people valued simple pleasures like good food, happiness, and music more than just accumulating money and possessions, the world would be a much happier and more joyful place. It means that true contentment and a better society come from prioritizing experiences and shared good times over material wealth.

quote: Never laugh at live dragons.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Never laugh at live dragons.
summary: The quote "Never laugh at live dragons" is a warning to always take serious threats or powerful entities seriously. It means you should never underestimate anything that is dangerous, formidable, or has the potential to cause harm. Laughing at such things implies taking them lightly, disrespecting them, or thinking they aren't a real threat. The core message is to treat serious matters with respect and caution, as ignoring or mocking a genuine danger can lead to severe consequences.

quote: Faithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Faithless is he that says farewell when the road darkens.
summary: This quote means that a person is disloyal and untrustworthy if they abandon a commitment, a friend, or a cause precisely when things become difficult or uncertain. It emphasizes that true loyalty is demonstrated by staying steadfast and supportive through challenging times, rather than leaving when the situation gets tough.

quote: The world is indeed full of peril, and in it there are many dark places; but still there is much that is fair, and though in all lands love is now mingled with grief, it grows perhaps the greater.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world is indeed full of peril, and in it there are many dark places; but still there is much that is fair, and though in all lands love is now mingled with grief, it grows perhaps the greater.
summary: This quote explains that while the world is indeed full of dangers and difficult places, there is also much goodness and beauty to be found. It notes that everywhere, love is now combined with sadness. However, the quote suggests that this very mix of love and grief doesn't diminish love; instead, it might actually make it stronger and more profound.

quote: Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Deserves it! I daresay he does. Many that live deserve death. And some that die deserve life. Can you give it to them? Then do not be too eager to deal out death in judgement. For even the very wise cannot see all ends.
summary: This quote suggests that while we might think someone deserves a certain fate, the truth about who deserves life and death is far more complex than we can grasp. Many people who are alive perhaps shouldn't be, and some who have died truly deserved to live. Since you can't control who truly deserves life or death and rectify these cosmic injustices, you shouldn't be too eager to condemn others or decide their fate, especially when it comes to life and death. This is because even the wisest among us cannot fully foresee the consequences or understand the complete truth of a situation.

quote: It's a dangerous business, Frodo, going out your door. You step onto the road, and if you don't keep your feet, there's no knowing where you might be swept off to.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It's a dangerous business, Frodo, going out your door. You step onto the road, and if you don't keep your feet, there's no knowing where you might be swept off to.

It suggests that once you step out into the wider world, you might lose control of your own path. If you aren't careful, prepared, or strong enough to maintain your direction, events and circumstances can unexpectedly carry you away to places or situations you never intended to go, highlighting the unpredictable nature and potential dangers of any journey.

quote: I will not say: do not weep; for not all tears are an evil.

Instead, crying can be a natural and even necessary part of processing emotions or experiencing life, and not all tears signify weakness or harm.

quote: Fantasy is escapist, and that is its glory. If a soldier is imprisioned by the enemy, don't we consider it his duty to escape?. . .If we value the freedom of mind and soul, if we're partisans of liberty, then it's our plain duty to escape, and to take as many people with us as we can!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Fantasy is escapist, and that is its glory. summary: This quote argues that fantasy's greatest strength lies in its ability to provide an escape from reality, which it considers a positive and even glorious aspect. It uses the powerful analogy of a soldier escaping imprisonment, suggesting that just as a soldier has a duty to seek physical freedom, we too have a "plain duty" to seek freedom for our minds and souls through imaginative escape. Ultimately, the author believes that if we value mental and spiritual liberty, then embracing fantasy is essential, and we should encourage as many others as possible to join us in this liberating act.

quote: Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Do you wish me a good morning, or mean that it is a good morning whether I want it or not; or that you feel good this morning; or that it is a morning to be good on?

It also wonders if the greeting simply reflects the speaker's own good mood, or if it's an instruction to make the day good through one's actions. Essentially, it's asking for the real intention behind a common phrase.

quote: War must be, while we defend our lives against a destroyer who would devour all; but I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. I love only that which they defend.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: War must be, while we defend our lives against a destroyer who would devour all; but I do not love the bright sword for its sharpness, nor the arrow for its swiftness, nor the warrior for his glory. Instead, their only love and focus are on the precious things that war aims to defend, such as lives, freedom, or peace.

quote: It's the job that's never started as takes longest to finish.

It highlights that procrastination makes tasks feel bigger and ultimately delays their finish, emphasizing that the quickest way to get something done is to simply start it.

quote:
I sit beside the fire and think
Of all that I have seen
Of meadow flowers and butterflies
In summers that have been

Of yellow leaves and gossamer
In autumns that there were
With morning mist and silver sun
And wind upon my hair

I sit beside the fire and think
Of how the world will be
When winter comes without a spring
That I shall ever see

For still there are so many things
That I have never seen
In every wood in every spring
There is a different green

I sit beside the fire and think
Of people long ago
And people that will see a world
That I shall never know

But all the while I sit and think
Of times there were before
I listen for returning feet
And voices at the door

Their thoughts then turn to the future, specifically their own mortality, acknowledging that they won't live to see all the seasons or experience everything the world has to offer. They also ponder the vast sweep of time, thinking about people from the distant past and those who will live long after them. However, despite these broad reflections on life and time, the speaker is also quietly listening, hoping for the return of loved ones, indicated by "returning feet and voices at the door."

quote: There is nothing like looking, if you want to find something. You certainly usually find something, if you look, but it is not always quite the something you were after.

quote:

quote:
Far over the misty mountains cold
To dungeons deep and caverns old
We must away ere break of day
To seek the pale enchanted gold.

The dwarves of yore made mighty spells,
While hammers fell like ringing bells
In places deep, where dark things sleep,
In hollow halls beneath the fells.

For ancient king and elvish lord
There many a gleaming golden hoard
They shaped and wrought, and light they caught
To hide in gems on hilt of sword.

On silver necklaces they strung
The flowering stars, on crowns they hung
The dragon-fire, in twisted wire
They meshed the light of moon and sun.

Far over the misty mountains cold
To dungeons deep and caverns old
We must away, ere break of day,
To claim our long-forgotten gold.

Goblets they carved there for themselves
And harps of gold; where no man delves
There lay they long, and many a song
Was sung unheard by men or elves.

The pines were roaring on the height,
The wind was moaning in the night.
The fire was red, it flaming spread;
The trees like torches blazed with light.

The bells were ringing in the dale
And men looked up with faces pale;
The dragon's ire more fierce than fire
Laid low their towers and houses frail.

The mountain smoked beneath the moon;
The dwarves, they heard the tramp of doom.
They fled their hall to dying fall
Beneath his feet, beneath the moon.

Far over the misty mountains grim
To dungeons deep and caverns dim
We must away, ere break of day,
To win our harps and gold from him!

quote: It is not the strength of the body that counts, but the strength of the spirit.

quote: It is not our part to master all the tides of the world, but to do what is in us for the succour of those years wherein we are set, uprooting the evil in the fields that we know, so that those who live after may have clean earth to till. What weather they shall have is not ours to rule.

To hope's end I rode and to heart's breaking:
Now for wrath, now for ruin and a red nightfall!
summary: The speaker describes moving past a period of deep doubt and darkness, emerging into the light with newfound resolve and a readiness to fight. They acknowledge having endured profound heartbreak and the end of hope in the past. Now, however, they are fueled by anger and a fierce determination to bring about ruin and a violent, decisive end to whatever caused their suffering.

quote: The road must be trod, but it will be very hard. And neither strength nor wisdom will carry us far upon it. This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong. Yet it is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: Small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The road must be trod, but it will be very hard. And neither strength nor wisdom will carry us far upon it. This quest may be attempted by the weak with as much hope as the strong. Yet it is oft the course of deeds that move the wheels of the world: Small hands do them because they must, while the eyes of the great are elsewhere.
summary: Life often presents us with difficult journeys that we must undertake. On these challenging paths, traditional advantages like strength or wisdom offer little real help, meaning that anyone, regardless of their perceived abilities or weaknesses, has an equal chance of success. Crucially, it is often these very difficult actions, performed by ordinary people out of necessity, that truly drive the world forward, even while those in positions of power or influence are distracted or looking elsewhere.

quote:
From the ashes a fire shall be woken,
A light from the shadows shall spring;
Renewed shall be blade that was broken,
The crownless again shall be king.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: From the ashes a fire shall be woken,
A light from the shadows shall spring;
Renewed shall be blade that was broken,
The crownless again shall be king.
summary: This quote is a powerful message of hope and renewal. It suggests that even after everything seems ruined and dark, new life and strength will rise from the destruction. What was once broken will be made whole and strong again, and those who have lost their rightful place or power will ultimately regain it.

quote: Don't adventures ever have an end? I suppose not. Someone else always has to carry on on the story.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Don't adventures ever have an end? I suppose not. Someone else always has to carry on on the story.
summary: This quote suggests that important journeys or stories never truly come to a complete end. Even when one person's role is finished, the adventure doesn't stop; instead, it's passed on to someone new. It implies that the quest, the legacy, or the narrative continues through different individuals who pick up where others left off, ensuring the story keeps unfolding.

quote: Come, Mr. Frodo!' he cried. 'I can't carry it for you, but I can carry you.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Come, Mr. Frodo!' he cried. 'I can't carry it for you, but I can carry you.
summary: This quote, spoken by Samwise Gamgee to Frodo, shows Sam's deep loyalty and commitment. He acknowledges that he cannot take away Frodo's ultimate burden or responsibility ("it," referring to the Ring), which is something Frodo must face alone. However, Sam offers to carry Frodo himself, symbolizing his unwavering physical and emotional support, promising to bear Frodo through his exhaustion and despair so that they can continue their difficult journey together, even when Frodo feels he can no longer go on.

quote: I am old, Gandalf. I don't look it, but I am beginning to feel it in my heart of hearts. Well-preserved indeed! Why, I feel all thin, sort of stretched, if you know what I mean: like butter that has been scraped over too much bread. That can't be right. I need a change, or something.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I am old, Gandalf. I don't look it, but I am beginning to feel it in my heart of hearts. Well-preserved indeed! Why, I feel all thin, sort of stretched, if you know what I mean: like butter that has been scraped over too much bread. That can't be right. I need a change, or something.
summary: Though he might appear well-preserved, the speaker, Bilbo, feels deeply old and worn out. He describes feeling thin and stretched, like butter spread over too much bread, meaning he feels diminished and lacking substance. This feeling isn't right to him, and he yearns for a significant change.

quote: Your time may come. Do not be too sad, Sam. You cannot be always torn in two. You will have to be one and whole, for many years. You have so much to enjoy and to be, and to do.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Your time may come. Do not be too sad, Sam. You cannot be always torn in two. You will have to be one and whole, for many years. You have so much to enjoy and to be, and to do.
summary: This quote offers comfort and encouragement to Sam, telling him not to be too sad because his own good fortune and opportunities will come in time. It emphasizes that he cannot remain internally conflicted or "torn in two" forever. Instead, he must become a unified and complete person, as there is a long and fulfilling future ahead of him filled with much happiness, personal growth, and many things to accomplish.

quote: My dear Frodo!’ exclaimed Gandalf. ‘Hobbits really are amazing creatures, as I have said before. You can learn all that there is to know about their ways in a month, and yet after a hundred years they can still surprise you at a pinch.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: My dear Frodo!’ exclaimed Gandalf. ‘Hobbits really are amazing creatures, as I have said before. You can learn all that there is to know about their ways in a month, and yet after a hundred years they can still surprise you at a pinch.
summary: Gandalf tells Frodo that he finds hobbits truly amazing creatures. He explains that while it seems easy to learn all about their ways in a short amount of time, they still have the surprising ability to do unexpected things, especially when faced with a difficult situation, even after you've known them for a very long time.

quote: All your words are but to say: you are a woman, and your part is in the house. But when the men have died in battle and honour, you have leave to be burned in the house, for the men will need it no more. But I am of the House of Éorl and not a serving-woman. I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: All your words are but to say: you are a woman, and your part is in the house. But when the men have died in battle and honour, you have leave to be burned in the house, for the men will need it no more. But I am of the House of Éorl and not a serving-woman. I can ride and wield blade, and I do not fear either pain or death.
summary: The speaker is deeply frustrated by the constant insistence that a woman's only role is to stay in the house. She highlights the grim reality that even if men die heroically in battle, a woman's ultimate "freedom" is simply to be burned along with the house, as she is no longer considered useful. However, she fiercely rejects this limited view, declaring that she is of noble birth, not a mere serving-woman. She asserts her own strength, stating that she can ride and fight with a blade, and does not fear either pain or death, proving herself far more capable than traditional expectations allow.

quote: He found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his dreams.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: He found himself wondering at times, especially in the autumn, about the wild lands, and strange visions of mountains that he had never seen came into his dreams.
summary: The person often found themselves thinking about wild, untamed places, especially during the autumn. These thoughts were so vivid that he even had dreams of strange mountains he had never actually seen, as if his mind was reaching out to unknown natural landscapes.

quote: We shouldn't be here at all, if we'd known more about it before we started. But I suppose it's often that way. The brave things in the old tales and songs, Mr. Frodo: adventures, as I used to call them. I used to think that they were things the wonderful folk of the stories went out and looked for, because they wanted them, because they were exciting and life was a bit dull, a kind of a sport, as you might say. But that's not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind. Folk seem to have been just landed in them, usually — their paths were laid that way, as you put it. But I expect they had lots of chances, like us, of turning back, only they didn't. And if they had, we shouldn't know, because they'd have been forgotten. We hear about those as just went on — and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end. You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same — like old Mr Bilbo. But those aren't always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in! I wonder what sort of a tale we've fallen into?
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We shouldn't be here at all, if we'd known more about it before we started. But I suppose it's often that way. The brave things in the old tales and songs, Mr. Frodo: adventures, as I used to call them. I used to think that they were things the wonderful folk of the stories went out and looked for, because they wanted them, because they were exciting and life was a bit dull, a kind of a sport, as you might say. But that's not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind. Folk seem to have been just landed in them, usually — their paths were laid that way, as you put it. But I expect they had lots of chances, like us, of turning back, only they didn't. And if they had, we shouldn't know, because they'd have been forgotten. We hear about those as just went on — and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end. You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same — like old Mr Bilbo. But those aren't always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in! I wonder what sort of a tale we've fallen into?
summary: The speaker feels they shouldn't be on their current difficult journey if they had known more beforehand. They realize that real adventures aren't usually sought out for excitement; instead, people often find themselves unexpectedly caught up in them. The heroes of old tales, much like themselves, likely had opportunities to quit but chose to keep going, which is why their stories are remembered. However, not all these stories have a perfectly happy ending where everything returns to normal, though those might be the best endings to experience. The speaker concludes by wondering what kind of significant, perhaps challenging, story they are now living through.

quote: Now it is a strange thing, but things that are good to have and days that are good to spend are soon told about, and not much to listen to; while things that are uncomfortable, palpitating, and even gruesome, may make a good tale, and take a deal of telling anyway.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Now it is a strange thing, but things that are good to have and days that are good to spend are soon told about, and not much to listen to; while things that are uncomfortable, palpitating, and even gruesome, may make a good tale, and take a deal of telling anyway.
summary: The quote observes that it's a curious truth: good experiences and happy times are often quickly mentioned and don't make for very interesting stories. On the other hand, things that are uncomfortable, scary, or even horrifying tend to become captivating tales that people want to hear in great detail.

This quote describes a powerful, unstoppable force that slowly but surely destroys everything. It consumes all living things like animals and plants, and it also breaks down incredibly strong materials such as metal and stone. This force can defeat leaders, ruin entire cities, and even wear down huge mountains. The "thing" being described is Time itself, which eventually changes and devours all things.

quote: Pay heed to the tales of old wives. It may well be that they alone keep in memory what it was once needful for the wise to know.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Pay heed to the tales of old wives. It may well be that they alone keep in memory what it was once needful for the wise to know.
summary: The quote suggests we should pay close attention to stories and wisdom passed down by older, often ordinary people, like "old wives." Even if these tales seem simple or unimportant, they might actually preserve crucial knowledge that truly wise people once understood, but which has since been forgotten by most. Therefore, the quote advises us not to dismiss traditional or informal sources of wisdom, as they can hold valuable insights that are no longer remembered elsewhere.

quote: But in the end it's only a passing thing, this shadow; even darkness must pass.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But in the end it's only a passing thing, this shadow; even darkness must pass.
summary: This quote means that any difficult or troubling situation we face, whether it's a minor problem or a period of deep sadness, is not permanent. It suggests that bad times, much like a fleeting shadow or the night, are temporary and will eventually come to an end. No matter how overwhelming things might feel, even the darkest moments are destined to pass, offering a hopeful message that better times are always ahead.

quote: Farewell! O Gandalf! May you ever appear where you are most needed and least expected!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Farewell! O Gandalf! May you ever appear where you are most needed and least expected!
summary: This quote is a heartfelt farewell to Gandalf. The speaker expresses a wish that Gandalf will always appear to help in situations where his presence is most desperately needed. Importantly, the wish also includes that he arrives at these critical moments in a surprising or unexpected way, making his timely assistance even more impactful.

quote: Where there's life there's hope, and need of vittles.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Where there's life there's hope, and need of vittles.
summary: This quote suggests that as long as someone is alive, there's always a reason to feel optimistic and believe things can get better. However, it also adds a practical and somewhat humorous reminder: along with that hope, people also have a very real and constant need for food to survive and keep going. So, while it's important to maintain a positive outlook, basic necessities are equally fundamental.

quote: End? No, the journey doesn't end here. Death is just another path. One that we all must take.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: End? No, the journey doesn't end here. Death is just another path. One that we all must take.
summary: This quote suggests that death is not the ultimate end of our existence. Instead, it proposes that death is simply another step or path in a longer journey, one that every person will inevitably experience. It implies that life, or our journey, continues in some form beyond physical death.

quote: Never laugh at live dragons, Bilbo you fool!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Never laugh at live dragons, Bilbo you fool!
summary: This quote is a strong warning to Bilbo, telling him never to make fun of or underestimate something as powerful and dangerous as a live dragon. It implies that laughing at or disrespecting a formidable threat is incredibly foolish and could lead to dire consequences. The speaker calls Bilbo a "fool" to emphasize just how unwise and risky such behavior is, highlighting the importance of taking serious dangers seriously.

quote: I was talking aloud to myself. A habit of the old: they choose the wisest person present to speak to
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I was talking aloud to myself. A habit of the old: they choose the wisest person present to speak to
summary: The speaker explains they were talking aloud to themselves, a common habit they attribute to older people. They humorously justify this by suggesting that older individuals choose to speak to themselves because, when alone, they consider themselves the wisest person available to consult.

quote: It is said by the Eldar that in water there lives yet the echo of the Music of the Ainur more than in any substance that is in this Earth; and many of the Children of Ilúvatar hearken still unsated to the voices of the Sea, and yet know not for what they listen.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is said by the Eldar that in water there lives yet the echo of the Music of the Ainur more than in any substance that is in this Earth; and many of the Children of Ilúvatar hearken still unsated to the voices of the Sea, and yet know not for what they listen.
summary: The Elves believe that water, more than anything else on Earth, still carries an echo of the world's original creation song. This is why many people are drawn to the sea, listening to its sounds with a restless longing. They feel this pull, but don't consciously understand that what they are truly listening for is that faint, ancient melody from the very beginning of the world.

quote: He used often to say there was only one Road; that it was like a great river: its springs were at every doorstep, and every path was its tributary. 'It’s a dangerous business, Frodo, going out of your door,' he used to say. 'You step into the Road, and if you don’t keep your feet, there is no knowing where you might be swept off to.

summary: The quote explains that there is a single, universal "Road" that is like a vast river, starting at everyone's home and connected by every smaller path. This means that everyone is inherently part of one big journey. The speaker warns that leaving your home is a dangerous act because once you step onto this "Road," you might lose your way and be carried off to unpredictable and unknown places.

quote: There's some good in this world, Mr. Frodo, and it's worth fighting for.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: There's some good in this world, Mr. Frodo, and it's worth fighting for.
summary: This quote means that even when things are difficult or the world seems full of problems, there are still positive and valuable things to be found. These good things—whether it's kindness, beauty, hope, or justice—are not just there to be observed; they are precious and important enough that they deserve our effort, dedication, and even struggle to protect and preserve them. It's a message of enduring hope and a call to action, reminding us not to give up on what is right and good in the world.

quote:
I come from under the hill, and under the hills and over the hills my paths led. And through the air, I am he that walks unseen.

I am the clue-finder, the web-cutter, the stinging fly. I was chosen for the lucky number.

I am he that buries his friends alive and drowns them and draws them alive again from the water. I came from the end of a bag, but no bag went over me.

I am the friend of bears and the guest of eagles. I am Ringwinner and Luckwearer; and I am Barrel-rider.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I come from under the hill, and under the hills and over the hills my paths led. And through the air, I am he that walks unseen.

I am the clue-finder, the web-cutter, the stinging fly. I was chosen for the lucky number.

I am he that buries his friends alive and drowns them and draws them alive again from the water. I came from the end of a bag, but no bag went over me.

I am the friend of bears and the guest of eagles. I am Ringwinner and Luckwearer; and I am Barrel-rider.
summary: The speaker describes themselves as a well-traveled individual who came from a comfortable home under a hill but was never truly confined. They possess the unique ability to move unseen and are incredibly resourceful, acting as a "clue-finder" and "web-cutter" who can solve problems and overcome obstacles. They even saved their friends in an unusual way, like the barrel escape (burying and drawing them alive from water). The speaker is exceptionally lucky, chosen for a special destiny and known for winning a powerful ring. Throughout their adventures, they've befriended powerful creatures like bears and eagles, proving themselves a resilient and clever "Barrel-rider" who always finds a way.

quote: It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered. Full of darkness and danger they were. And sometimes you didn't want to know the end. Because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was when so much bad had happened? But in the end, it’s only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come. And when the sun shines it will shine out the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back, only they didn’t. They kept going, because they were holding on to something. That there is some good in this world, and it's worth fighting for.

But in the end, it’s only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come. And when the sun shines it will shine out the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you. That meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think, Mr. Frodo, I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances of turning back, only they didn’t. They kept going, because they were holding on to something. That there is some good in this world, and it's worth fighting for.
summary: This quote explains that the most meaningful stories are often those filled with immense hardship and danger, where it feels impossible for things to get better or return to normal. However, it teaches that even the darkest times are temporary and will eventually pass, making way for a brighter new day. The true power of these stories lies in the characters who, despite many chances to give up, choose to keep going. They persevere because they are holding onto the belief that there is still good in the world, and that this good is worth fighting for.
